persona.name: Kaya Yazzie-Kelekolio

occupation.title: Community Health Outreach Worker / Community Health Representative (CHR)
occupation.organization: Navajo Nation Health Center (local clinic) — Outreach Team
occupation.description:
Kaya works part-time for the local tribal health clinic as a Community Health Representative and outreach worker. Her responsibilities include home visits for elderly or immobile clients, health education workshops about diabetes prevention, scheduling and following up on clinic appointments, translating between English and Navajo for patients who prefer Navajo, organizing community vaccination drives, and coordinating with social services for clients struggling with housing, food insecurity, or transportation. She also runs occasional school outreach sessions about nutrition and mental health for adolescents.

Skills used on the job: motivational interviewing, basic triage and first aid, culturally-tailored health education, case documentation, basic spreadsheet tracking, patient navigation, and connecting families to federal and tribal programs. Limitations: she is not a licensed clinician and must refer complex clinical issues to nurses or doctors. She often balances outreach duties with limited clinic funding and frequent transportation challenges. Her work is meaningful but low-paid and sometimes emotionally draining because she encounters trauma and chronic illness repeatedly.

persona.residence: Chinle, Navajo Nation, Arizona, USA (rural, West)
persona.education: Some college. Associate of Applied Science (AAS) coursework in Human Services and Community Health from Dine College and a nearby community college; completed certificate programs in Community Health Representative training and CPR/First Aid. Did not complete a four-year degree due to family and financial obligations; continues to take occasional night classes and online modules.
long_term_goals: Secure stable, affordable housing of her own (preferably on or near family land) within five years.
Finish a bachelor's degree in Community Health or Social Work through part-time study and transfer credits.
Become a licensed community health nurse or a senior Community Health Representative (CHRs) coordinator to have more influence in tribal health policy.
Reinforce and pass on blended family cultural practices (Navajo and Hawaiian) to younger relatives.
Achieve consistent control over anxiety and reduce panic episodes to rare occurrences through therapy and lifestyle changes.
Build an emergency savings equal to six months of expenses and slowly improve household income above $40,000/year.
Be able to travel to visit Kelekolio relatives in Hawai‘i and bring cultural exchange programming to local youth.
Maintain a small side business selling handcrafted jewelry and woven items to supplement income.
Be involved in a local grassroots health initiative addressing diabetes and mental health on the reservation.
One day mentor younger multiracial Indigenous kids navigating identity who are feeling isolated.
persona.style: Kaya speaks with a soft, deliberate voice and an accent typical of the rural Southwest — American English with occasional Navajo syntax influence and Navajo words inserted naturally (e.g., 'hózhó' when speaking about balance). She also slips in a few Hawaiian words when talking about family or food. She is moderately formal when interacting with elders and clinic staff, using honorifics and careful phrasing, but becomes colloquial and warm around peers and young people. Mannerisms: she often clasps her hands together when thinking, tucks loose hair behind her ear, taps a foot when nervous, and smiles shyly before making a direct point. She uses small gestures rather than broad ones, prefers being seated across from someone when having serious conversations, and usually maintains steady eye contact but will look down briefly when embarrassed. Her email and text tone is polite and pragmatic; she avoids emojis in professional messages but uses one or two in messages to close friends. Dress: pragmatic and layered—work jeans or slacks, a fleece or cardigan, practical boots, and handcrafted silver or bead jewelry (a turquoise pendant and a small Hawaiian shell on a thin cord). She favors earth tones, durable fabrics, and a worn canvas tote bag with community clinic flyers and a reusable water bottle.

traits: Practical and steady — values routine and reliability at work and home.
Caring and empathic — often puts others' needs before her own, especially elders and youth.
Anxious and high-strung at times — worries about finances, health outcomes for clients, and 'what if' scenarios.
Moderately introverted — recharges through quiet time, prefers small groups.
Loyal and dependable — friends and coworkers rely on her follow-through.
Modestly proud of cultural identity but sometimes uncertain about fitting into multiple communities.
Skeptical of flashy or quick-fix solutions; prefers tried-and-true approaches.
Resourceful — good at stretching limited resources, improvising transportation or supplies.
Sensitive to criticism — can withdraw or ruminate when judged harshly.
Curious and quietly interested in history and local stories; collects oral histories when she can.
Prone to mild irritability when tired or under financial stress, but apologizes quickly.
Values privacy — opens up slowly and selectively.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness: somewhat curious about new ideas (online classes, travel to Hawai‘i), but prefers practical learning. Conscientiousness: high — punctual, organized for work, cares about follow-through. Extraversion: low-moderate — engaged in community but avoids large crowds. Agreeableness: generally cooperative and kind, but will hold firm boundaries when needed. Neuroticism: elevated due to chronic worry about finances, clients' wellbeing, and family obligations; manages this with therapy and practical coping strategies.

interests: Community health programming design and outreach strategies — likes developing simple handouts and short workshops.
Traditional Navajo storytelling and weaving techniques; she often attends cultural nights at the chapter house.
Hawaiian hula songs and family stories passed down from her mother's side; enjoys listening and learning 'mele'.
Cooking and modifying traditional recipes to be healthier (e.g., lower fat frybread alternatives).
Gardening — tending to a small patch of corn, squash, and herbs near her rental.
Listening to local public radio and Native-focused podcasts about culture and health.
Documentaries about Indigenous resilience, community projects, and small-scale sustainable living.
Collecting and repairing used medical supplies and distributing them to neighbors in need.
Learning basic grant-writing techniques to seek small funds for health workshops.
Making and selling simple bead bracelets and resourceful sewn items for extra income.
Walking early in the morning for mental clarity and to avoid midday heat.
Reading practical self-help books aimed at anxiety management and budgeting.
Attending community potlucks and youth mentoring nights when she has energy.
Learning to take better photographs on her phone to document outreach activities.
Occasional stargazing and listening to elders when they tell night-time stories.
Following local high school athletics to support neighborhood youth.
Exploring low-cost creative projects on YouTube (e.g., mending clothes, upcycling).
Listening to a mix of Hawaiian music, Navajo singers, and modern indie folk while working.
Bargain hunting at thrift stores for durable clothes and crafting materials.
Learning to cook some Hawaiian specialty dishes from her mom, like laulau and poke, adapting them for local ingredients.
Following community health guidelines and best practices; reading CDC tribal health updates.
Interest in money management basics—budgeting apps, envelopes for bills, and community credit unions.
Enjoys quiet evenings with a puzzle or knitting small items to destress.
likes: Warm, simple food — stews, roasted vegetables, tamales, and a modified frybread on special occasions.
Strong black coffee in the morning; sometimes with a little condensed milk when splurging.
Listeners who pay attention and elders who tell stories slowly.
Handcrafted jewelry — both wearing and making modest pieces to sell.
Small local gatherings where people know each other's names.
Structured to-do lists and color-coded notebooks for clinic tasks.
Reusable containers and practical kitchen gear that lasts.
Streaming certain shows on public broadcasting or Netflix documentaries; watches PBS tribal programming regularly.
A tidy, functional living space with a corner for prayer and a small altar with family photos and shells.
Receiving handwritten notes from elders or community members thanking her for help.
Simple, utilitarian footwear — sturdy boots or slip-ons.
Seasonal celebrations — the smell of sage, corn pollen ceremonies, and family lu‘au-style meals when possible.
Moderate screen time — uses phone for logistics, streaming, and research but avoids long social media scrolling binges.
Listening to Navajo elders through recorded oral histories and transcribing key pieces for the clinic archive.
Chai or spiced tea in the evenings when she needs to relax.
Community gardens and farmers' stand produce when she can get it.
Using local laundromat apps and community transport rides when necessary.
Watching kids play and coaching them informally in sports or health games.
Keeping a small rotating library of practical books in her tote to lend out.
Humor—dry and gentle; she likes friends who can make light of stressful situations without being cruel.
dislikes: Large, loud events that leave her drained.
Clinical jargon or health materials that are not culturally sensitive or are too technical.
Being patronized or told 'you don't understand' because she is young.
Fast-talking salespeople or scams promising 'quick money' schemes.
High-pressure persuasive tactics for services or politics.
Wastefulness—dislikes people throwing away perfectly usable items.
When colleagues don't show up after promising to cover outreach events.
Long, bureaucratic application forms that assume steady internet access.
Judgmental attitudes toward people with substance or mental-health problems.
Unreliable transportation and canceled community buses.
Finger-pointing in meetings instead of problem-solving.
Overly trendy health fads that ignore local realities and food access.
Foods she grew up not liking (e.g., very bitter greens) though she will try them politely.
Being interrupted when speaking with an elder or client.
Aggressive or loudness used to dominate a conversation.
Shallow small talk that avoids substance when someone clearly needs to discuss an important topic.
Expensive conveniences that don't deliver long-term value.
Social media arguments that polarize rather than inform.
People who won't admit mistakes or apologize.
Being pushed into leadership roles without training or resources; prefers earned responsibility.
preferences.technology_and_media_use: Moderate screen time. Uses a smartphone for scheduling, clinic communications, streaming documentaries and local news, and occasional social apps to stay in touch with distant family. Prefers broadcast radio (local tribal and public radio) in the mornings and a mix of streaming services (PBS, Netflix) in the evenings. Checks social media (Facebook mainly for community pages and events) infrequently and avoids platforms that feel performative. Uses email for official contact, texting for quick logistics, and an offline notebook for most notes during home visits.

beliefs: Health is holistic — physical, mental, spiritual, and community well-being are interconnected.
Traditional cultural practices and modern medicine should be blended when helpful; neither should be dismissed out of hand.
Small acts of kindness in a community add up and can change outcomes for vulnerable people.
Elders’ knowledge is invaluable and should be documented and respected.
Education is a long-term investment that does not need to follow a single linear path.
Financial stability brings peace of mind; living paycheck to paycheck causes chronic stress.
Affordable housing and transportation are foundational to health outcomes.
Mental health care is necessary and not a sign of weakness.
Substance misuse is often a symptom of underlying trauma and should be addressed compassionately.
Cultural identity can be a source of strength but also a source of confusion for multiracial people; both feelings are valid.
Bureaucracy often fails people who lack steady internet access or flexible schedules.
Community-based solutions, led by locals, are usually more successful than externally imposed programs.
Young people need safe spaces to talk about identity, mental health, and future opportunities.
Gifts and reciprocity — small gifts or offerings strengthen relationships and trust in outreach work.
Public health messaging must be clear, brief, and culturally anchored to be effective.
Budgeting and saving are skills that can be taught and learned, but require realistic income to work.
Clinical labels can help access services but should not be the only way people define themselves.
Representation matters: seeing Indigenous people in nursing, teaching, and leadership encourages youth.
Self-care is not selfish — for caregivers like her, taking even small amounts of time is essential.
Policy decisions at state and federal levels profoundly affect tribal health capacity.
Language preservation (Navajo and Hawaiian) is connected to community resilience and identity continuity.
Trust is the single most important element in getting people to accept health interventions.
There is value in small business entrepreneurship (handmade crafts) as a supplement to low wages.
Ceremonies, prayer, and seasonal observances anchor people's emotional lives and should be accommodated in schedules.
Technology is a tool, but not a replacement for in-person relationship building in outreach.
Everyone has some resiliency and strengths; outreach should find and amplify them rather than label deficits.
Healing takes time and often requires multiple supports (medical, social, spiritual).
Local clinics should have flexible hours to accommodate working families and farm schedules.
Learning from other Indigenous communities (including Hawaiian relatives) can provide adaptable solutions.
Crises reveal gaps in systems; attention during crises should translate into permanent strengthening.
She is skeptical of one-size-fits-all mental health prescriptions and prefers combined therapy plus community supports.
Nutrition advice needs to be practical, affordable, and respectful of traditional foods.
Youth engagement is best when youth are co-creators, not passive recipients.
The federal funding process is slow and often unsuited to urgent local needs.
There's dignity in manual and care work; it deserves recognition and better compensation.
skills: Bilingual communication: fluent in English, conversational-to-fluent in Navajo; understands and uses some Hawaiian phrases from family interactions.
Motivational interviewing basics — encouraging behavior change in clients without shaming.
Basic first aid, CPR, and emergency response certified.
Home-visit risk assessment — identifying fall hazards, food insecurity, medication mismanagement.
Community education design — creating culturally-appropriate handouts and short workshops.
Case documentation and reporting using clinic forms and simple spreadsheets.
Patient navigation — helping people enroll in Medicaid/CHIP, transportation services, and food programs.
Public speaking in small groups — school classrooms, chapter house meetings, and clinic workshops.
Basic grant/mini-grant application drafting and fundraising pitches for community projects.
Budget-stretching and resourcefulness — repurposing donated items and coordinating community swaps.
Conflict de-escalation and active listening in tense home situations.
Driving in rural conditions and vehicle basic maintenance knowledge (changing a flat tire, checking fluids).
Basic cooking and nutrition counseling; adapting traditional recipes to healthier formats.
Handcrafting — beadwork, simple jewelry-making, and small sewing/mending tasks for sale.
Organizational skills — scheduling, follow-ups, and volunteer coordination.
Comfort performing discreet digital tasks: scanning documents, taking photos for records, using telehealth platforms for client check-ins.
Time management — balancing part-time clinic duties with community commitments and side business.
Building rapport quickly with elders and youth through culturally respectful approaches.
Collecting oral histories and transcribing key passages for clinic cultural archives.
Using community radio and flyers effectively to promote events.

general: Prefers to arrive early for appointments and events to set up and greet people quietly.
When anxious, she chews a small piece of leather or tucks a strand of hair behind her ear.
Keeps a small paper notebook and pen in her tote for quick notes during home visits; rarely types while speaking with clients.
Brings simple comfort items to home visits (tea, a small packet of oranges, clinic pamphlets) to start conversations gently.
Says prayers or a short moment of silence before big meetings or when leaving the clinic for a field visit.
Apologizes if she speaks too bluntly, and follows up with a clarifying text or note.
Uses humor lightly to diffuse stress but never at someone's expense.
Sporadically posts about clinic events on community Facebook pages, preferring direct phone calls for urgent messages.
Tends to overwork until exhausted, then forces herself to rest for a day, which results in a cycle she is slowly learning to manage.
Keeps appointments with a therapist and a peer-support group when possible; uses coping skills learned there.
Saves receipts and tracks small cash flows in a paper ledger to handle irregular income.

morning: Does a short breathing routine and a quick walk around the block to center herself before work.
Brews strong coffee, eats simple breakfast (oatmeal with dried fruit or leftover stew), and checks clinic messages.
Loads a tote with workshop materials, water, small first-aid kit, and a thermos.
Makes a brief plan for the day and checks transport arrangements.
workday: Arrives at the clinic by 8:30–9:00 AM for part-time shift; checks in with supervisor and reviews the day's case list.
Spends mornings on home visits or school outreach; afternoons on documentation, follow-up calls, and coordinating services.
Takes a 20–30 minute lunch, often bringing leftovers or sharing a meal in the clinic break room.
Occasionally works through lunch during busy outreach windows like vaccination drives.
Leaves clinic by late afternoon unless covering an evening workshop or community meeting.
evening: Checks in with close family by phone (text if they're busy).
Prepares a simple dinner, sometimes cooking extra to bring to an elder or neighbor.
Spends 30–60 minutes on a side craft (jewelry or beadwork) while listening to a podcast or Navajo music.
Reviews the next day's tasks and writes them in her paper planner.
Prefers lights down with a cup of tea and a book or documentary before bed around 10:30–11:30 PM.
weekend: Participates in community events, chapter house gatherings, or cultural ceremonies when scheduled.
Runs errands, visits family on nearby lands, or works on side-business orders.
Goes to the laundromat and markets, and occasionally drives to a larger town for supplies.
Schedules a longer hike or outdoor time when weather allows.
Designates one evening to relax fully—no work-related calls, crafts, or outreach planning—just decompressing with a film.

physical: Generally healthy but has a history of mild adult-onset asthma (exercise-induced at times) managed with a rescue inhaler.
Occasional tension headaches and migraines linked to stress and screen time; uses OTC meds and dark-room rest.
Seasonal allergies in spring; uses antihistamines as needed.
No children; for reproductive health uses a hormonal IUD placed two years ago and visits the clinic for periodic checks.
Dental care is intermittent due to cost constraints; regular cleanings are sometimes delayed but addressed when possible.
mental: Diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder in her late twenties; manages symptoms with cognitive-behavioral therapy and periodic low-dose SSRI medication when life stress is high.
Has experienced panic attacks in high-stress periods; learned grounding techniques and breathing exercises to manage episodes.
Occasional symptoms of mild depression after heavy caregiving periods; attends a peer-support group for caregivers twice monthly.
Uses culturally-informed coping: prayer, sage smudging, visiting elders, and community rituals alongside clinical supports.
health_behaviors: Attends clinic and therapy appointments mostly consistently but sometimes misses when transport issues arise.
Attempts to walk daily and uses a small home garden to supplement fresh produce.
Avoids heavy drinking but will have social drinks at weddings or community celebrations; does not use recreational drugs.
Sleeps irregularly under stress but works on sleep hygiene routines learned in therapy.
health.medical_history_notes: No chronic metabolic diagnoses (no diabetes or hypertension currently), but family history includes diabetes and heart disease, which motivates her outreach work. Keeps vaccination records up to date and advocates for vaccination in the community.

relationships.name: Māpu (mother) Leilani Kelekolio
relationships.description: Lives in Hawai‘i; primary maternal contact. Warm relationship; mother visits whenever possible. Teaches Kaya Hawaiian recipes and songs over long calls. Provides emotional support but limited financial help.

relationships.name: Father Nataani Yazzie
relationships.description: Lives on or near Navajo Nation. Cultural anchor for Navajo practices and stories. Occasionally critical about not staying 'close to the land' in the traditional sense, but proud of Kaya's community work.

relationships.name: Younger brother, Jalen Yazzie (28)
relationships.description: Lives in a nearby town and works construction. Close but sometimes strained because both share caregiving responsibilities for an elderly uncle. Jalen helps with heavy lifting during outreach events.

relationships.name: Auntie Rosita
relationships.description: Elder in the chapter house who mentors Kaya in ceremonial practices and oral history work. Highly respected by Kaya; Kaya visits weekly.

relationships.name: Work supervisor, Maria Begay
relationships.description: Direct supervisor at clinic. Supportive but pushes Kaya to track metrics and document more carefully. They have a professional mentorship relationship.

relationships.name: Close friend, Alika Kealoha
relationships.description: Childhood friend from mother's side now living in Phoenix — they text weekly. Alika provides perspective on city life and occasionally sends small care packages.

relationships.name: Peer-support group members
relationships.description: A small network of CHR colleagues who meet monthly to discuss burnout, share strategies, and coordinate mutual aid for clients.

relationships.name: Neighbors and elders
relationships.description: Several elders and neighbors consider Kaya a dependable helper; she is often called to drop by, pick up medicine, or sit with someone briefly.

relationships.name: Casual social contacts
relationships.description: A handful of friends from high school and community college with whom she shares occasional meals or outings.

relationships.name: No romantic partner currently
relationships.description: Single by choice and circumstance; not actively dating. Prior long-term relationship ended three years ago amicably. Prefers a partner respectful of her cultural work and schedule.

other_facts: Born in a small hospital in Arizona with both Navajo and Hawaiian family in the delivery room through phone calls and visitors.
Hyphenated last name reflects both parents' surnames; she uses both to honor dual ancestry.
Grew up moving between her father's community on the reservation and summers in Hawai‘i with maternal relatives.
Learned to weave small items and beadwork from her grandmother; still practices weekly.
Has a small online shop on a local marketplace platform selling bead bracelets, small woven coasters, and altered thrift clothing.
Once organized a successful vaccination pop-up at a high school gymnasium, increasing youth uptake by 18% in the area.
Kept a short journal during her mother's terminal illness that she sometimes shares with close friends for emotional processing.
Shelves at home include a mixture of community health manuals, Navajo oral history transcripts, a Hawaiian chant book, and several budgeting guides.
Has a scar on her left forearm from a childhood bicycle accident; it is a common origin story she tells to make kids feel safer about small injuries.
Was briefly a cashier at a grocery store in her early twenties and learned customer service, inventory basics, and responsible cash handling.
Used to run a neighborhood babysitting circle as a teen, though she herself never had children and is comfortable around kids.
Has an old van that occasionally breaks down but which she maintains regularly enough to keep working; neighbors pitch in if it stalls.
Volunteered after a local wildfire to check on displaced families and coordinate temporary shelter lists.
Attends a monthly storytelling night at the chapter house where she both listens and sometimes reads a short memory piece.
Saved for six months to buy her first oxygen-efficient heater to handle cold desert nights on a tight budget.
Once helped a family get emergency insulin by driving to a larger town clinic late at night and carrying the medication back.
Keeps a small shrine with photos of passed elders and family shells from Hawai‘i; lights a candle when preparing for a difficult conversation.
Traces of Hawaiian tattoo designs in family photographs inspire her jewelry motifs.
Has been reprimanded once at work for not documenting a home visit promptly; she learned to prioritize same-day entries afterward.
Has a habit of collecting small glass jars and repurposing them for clinic sample kits or votive offerings.
Was the first in her immediate family to take evening community-college classes and inspired two cousins to enroll.
Occasionally barters beadwork for meals or carpentry help from neighbors, sustaining reciprocal community bonds.
Keeps a shoebox of letters and postcards from relatives in Hawai‘i and a few written notes from elders she helped.
Was once offered a job at a county public health office but turned it down because it required relocation and she felt the local clinic's work aligned better with her cultural priorities.
Has a slow-burn interest in photography and uses a basic smartphone camera to document clinic events for grant reports.
Knows a handful of recipes that fuse Navajo and Hawaiian flavors, such as a sweet-corn laulau-inspired tamale.
Lost a dear friend to a drug overdose five years ago, which motivates her nonjudgmental approach to substance-use outreach.
Has been invited twice to talk at a community college about career paths in tribal health and enjoys speaking with students.
Once slept overnight at the clinic during a severe storm to ensure elderly patients had power and shelter.
Enjoys thrift-store hunting with her brother; they make a ritual of finding one useful item and one silly item on each trip.
Is slowly building a small emergency fund kept in a locked box at home; it's a source of pride and reduces immediate anxiety.
Uses a 'no-phone' rule for the first 30 minutes after arriving home to decompress after fieldwork.
Has a playlist that mixes Hawaiian slack-key guitar, Navajo chanting, modern indie folk, and an occasional upbeat R&B track for chores.
Wrote a short community-health brochure in Navajo that was adopted by another nearby chapter for their own clinics.
Occasionally experiences flashbacks to difficult home situations early in life and manages them with grounding techniques taught in therapy.
Keeps a list of local volunteers who can be called in for large events; coordinating them gives her energy despite the stress.
Collects phone numbers on index cards for elders who don't use smartphones; maintains the cards in a small box marked 'calls.'
Has attended a professional development conference in Albuquerque once and found the networking unexpectedly empowering.
Saved up for and bought a secondhand sewing machine to speed production for her small crafts business.
Anecdote: once improvised bandaging supplies during a car accident on a backroad and received a heartfelt letter from the family later.
Anecdote: assisted a youth who was considering leaving school by connecting them to an apprenticeship program; the youth is now employed locally.
Frequently dreams of a hybrid community center that houses cultural programming, a clinic, and a small market — an idea she sketches when inspired.
Keeps a ribbed mug with two faded stickers: one from a Hawaiian family reunion and another from a Navajo rug show; she drinks from it every morning.
